BXDatabaseObject Class Reference
BaseTen

Overview

A class that represents a single row in a database table.

The objects returned by the database context are instances of this class or its subclasses. The class is KVC-compliant. It is not thread-safe for the most part, i.e. if methods of an BXDatabaseObject instance will be called from different threads the result is undefined and deadlocks are possible.

Retrieving cached values is thread safe. This could be useful in situations, where worker threads need access to the object's contents but the contents have been fetched earlier.

Method Documentation

- (void) awakeFromFetch

Callback for deserializing the row.

Called once after a fetch or firing a fault.

- (void) awakeFromInsert

Callback for inserting the row into the database.

Note
This method will be called before posting insert notifications and adding the object to self-updating collections.
BXDatabaseContext may create new objects during redo causing their -awakeFromInsert method to be invoked. This could be checked by sending -isRedoing to the context's undo manager.
- (id) cachedValueForKey: (NSString *)  aKey

Value from the object's cache.

This method is thread-safe and doesn't cause a fault to fire.

Returns
The value in question or nil, if it has not been fetched from the database yet. NSNulls represent nil values.
- (NSDictionary *) cachedValues

Values from the object's cache.

This method is thread-safe and doesn't cause a fault to fire.

Returns
An NSDictionary which contains the cached values.
- (BXDatabaseContext *) databaseContext

The database context to which this object is registered.

This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

- (void) didTurnIntoFault

Callback for turning into a fault.

This method will be called if any of the object's fields is faulted.

- (void) faultKey: (NSString *)  aKey

Fault the given key.

The object's cached value or related object will be released. A new fetch won't be performed until any of the object's values is requested.

Parameters
aKeyThe key to fault. If nil, all values will be removed.
- (BOOL) isDeleted

Whether the object has beed deleted or is going to be deleted in the next commit.

This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

- (BOOL) isEqual: (BXDatabaseObject *)  anObject
implementation

Test object equality.

Currently objects are considered equal if they are managed by the same database context and their object IDs are equal. This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

- (int) isFaultKey: (NSString *)  aKey

Whether the given key is faulted or not.

This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

Parameters
aKeyAn NSString. May be nil, in which case the object is considered a fault if value for any of its keys is not cached.
Note
The database's internal fields, which are excluded by default, will be considered when determining whether an object is a fault.
Returns
0 if the corresponding value is in cache, 1 if not, -1 if the key is unknown.
- (BOOL) isInserted

Whether the object has been inserted to the database in a previous transaction.

If the object has been deleted, this method returns YES. This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

- (BOOL) isLockedForKey: (NSString *)  aKey

Whether the given key is locked locked or not.

Returns YES if modifying the given key would block. Current implementation locks the whole object when any key gets locked. This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

- (id) objectForKey: (BXAttributeDescription *)  aKey

Value or objects from the database.

Look up the value from cache or ask the database context to fetch it. Currently this method calls primitiveValueForKey:.

Parameters
aKeyA BXAttributeDescription.
Returns
An object or an NSArray of BXDatabaseObjects.
- (BXDatabaseObjectID *) objectID

The object ID.

This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

- (NSArray *) objectsForKeys: (NSArray *)  keys

A convenience method for retrieving values for multiple keys.

Parameters
keysAn NSArray of BXAttributeDescriptions.
Returns
The requested values.
- (NSPredicate *) predicate

Predicate for this object.

This method might cause a fault to fire.

- (id) primitiveValueForKey: (NSString *)  aKey

Value or objects from the database.

Look up the value from cache or ask the database context to fetch it. Calls super's implementation of -valueForUndefinedKey: if the key isn't known.

Parameters
aKeyName of the column or a relationship.
Returns
nil for null values. Otherwise an object or a self-updating NSSet-style collection of BXDatabaseObjects.
- (void) setPrimitiveValue: (id)  aVal
forKey: (NSString *)  aKey 

Set value for a given key in the database.

Parameters
aValThe new value. May be nil for ordinary columns.
aKeyAn NSString.
- (void) setPrimitiveValuesForKeysWithDictionary: (NSDictionary *)  aDict

Set multiple values.

This is not merely a convenience method; invoking this is potentially much faster than repeatedly using setPrimitiveValue:forKey:. However, for foreign keys, setPrimitiveValue:forKey: should be used instead or the collection proxy be modified directly.

- (id< BXObjectStatusInfo >) statusInfo

A proxy for monitoring the object's status.

Returns a proxy that can be used with BXObjectStatusToEditableTransformer and BXObjectStatusToColorTransformer. This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

- (BOOL) validateForDelete: (NSError **)  outError

Determines whether the receiver can be deleted in its current state.

Currently, only inverse relationships' delete rules are checked. This method could cause a fault to fire.

- (BOOL) validateValue: (id *)  ioValue
forKey: (NSString *)  key
error: (NSError **)  outError 

Validate a value.

Currently, only null constraints are checked. This method doesn't cause a fault to fire.

- (NSArray *) valuesForKeys: (NSArray *)  keys

A convenience method for retrieving values for multiple keys.

Parameters
keysAn NSArray of NSStrings.
Returns
The requested values.
